article: Recently divorced , I had no job and was on my way downtown to go the rounds of the employment offices despite the great  _  . My old umbrella was broken, and I could not  _  another one. I sat down in the streetcar -- and there against the seat was a beautiful silk  _  with a silver handle inlaid with gold. I had  _  seen anything so lovely. I  _  the handle and saw a  _  . I got off the streetcar and  _  opened the umbrella to protect myself. Then I searched a  _  book for the name on the umbrella and found it. I called and a lady answered. Yes, she said in  _  , that was her umbrella, which her parents, now dead, had given her for a birthday present.  _  , she added, it had been stolen at school (she was a teacher) more than a year before. She was so excited that I  _  I was  looking for  a job and went directly to her house. She took the umbrella, her  _  filled with tears. I refused the  _  she gave me. We talked for a while, and I must have given her my address. I don't remember. The next six months were  _  . I was able to obtain  _  here and there. l reached the lowest point in my  _  . Unless a miracle happened, I would be homeless in January, foodless, jobless. Christmas Eve came. No money to buy my daughter a gift. I was sobbing in the cold little kitchen  _  the doorbell rang and my daughter Peggy ran to answer it. He was a postman, and his arms were  _  of parcels. "This is a mistake" I said, but he read the name on the parcels and there were for me. Peggy and I sat on the floor and opened them. I looked for the name of the sender. It was the teacher. The address was  _  "California", where she had moved.
